activities.name: IngestTripDataIntoADLS
activities.description: Copies the trip data csv file from the git repo and loads it into the ADLS.

activities.name: IngestTripFaresDataIntoADLS
activities.description: Copies the trip fare data csv file from the git repo and loads it into the ADLS.

activities.name: JoinAndAggregateData
activities.description: Reads the raw data from both CSV files inside the ADLS, performs the desired transformations (inner join and aggregation) and writes the transformed data into the synapse SQL pool.

dependsOn.activity: Create Schema If Does Not Exists

activities.name: Create Schema If Does Not Exists
activities.description: Creates the schema inside the SQL dedicated pool. Shema name comes from the pipeline parameter 'SchemaName'.

sqlReaderQuery.value:
IF NOT EXISTS (SELECT * FROM sys.schemas WHERE name = '@{pipeline().parameters.SchemaName}')
BEGIN
EXEC('CREATE SCHEMA @{pipeline().parameters.SchemaName}')
select Count(*) from sys.symmetric_keys;
END
ELSE
BEGIN
    select Count(*) from sys.symmetric_keys;
END

dependsOn.activity: Create Schema If Does Not Exists

sink.preCopyScript:
IF (EXISTS (SELECT *
  FROM INFORMATION_SCHEMA.TABLES
  WHERE TABLE_SCHEMA = 'dbo'
  AND TABLE_NAME = 'TripsData'))
BEGIN 
   Truncate table TripsData;
End

dependsOn.activity: Create Schema If Does Not Exists

sink.preCopyScript:
IF (EXISTS (SELECT *
  FROM INFORMATION_SCHEMA.TABLES
  WHERE TABLE_SCHEMA = 'dbo'
  AND TABLE_NAME = 'FaresData'))
BEGIN 
   Truncate table FaresData;
End

typeProperties.script:
source(output(
		medallion as string,
		hack_license as string,
		vendor_id as string,
		rate_code as string,
		store_and_fwd_flag as string,
		pickup_datetime as string,
		dropoff_datetime as string,
		passenger_count as string,
		trip_time_in_secs as string,
		trip_distance as string,
		pickup_longitude as string,
		pickup_latitude as string,
		dropoff_longitude as string,
		dropoff_latitude as string
	),
	allowSchemaDrift: true,
	validateSchema: false,
	inferDriftedColumnTypes: true,
	ignoreNoFilesFound: false) ~> TripDataCSV
source(output(
		medallion as string,
		hack_license as string,
		vendor_id as string,
		pickup_datetime as string,
		payment_type as string,
		fare_amount as string,
		surcharge as string,
		mta_tax as string,
		tip_amount as string,
		tolls_amount as string,
		total_amount as string
	),
	allowSchemaDrift: true,
	validateSchema: false,
	inferDriftedColumnTypes: true,
	ignoreNoFilesFound: false) ~> FaresDataCSV
InnerJoinWithTripFares aggregate(groupBy(payment_type),
	average_fare = avg(toInteger(total_amount)),
		total_trip_distance = sum(toInteger(trip_distance))) ~> AggregateByPaymentType
TripDataCSV, FaresDataCSV join(TripDataCSV@medallion == FaresDataCSV@medallion
	&& TripDataCSV@hack_license == FaresDataCSV@hack_license
	&& TripDataCSV@vendor_id == FaresDataCSV@vendor_id
	&& TripDataCSV@pickup_datetime == FaresDataCSV@pickup_datetime,
	joinType:'inner',
	matchType:'exact',
	ignoreSpaces: false,
	broadcast: 'auto')~> InnerJoinWithTripFares
AggregateByPaymentType sink(allowSchemaDrift: true,
	validateSchema: false,
	deletable:false,
	insertable:true,
	updateable:false,
	upsertable:false,
	recreate:true,
	format: 'table',
	staged: false,
	skipDuplicateMapInputs: true,
	skipDuplicateMapOutputs: true,
	errorHandlingOption: 'stopOnFirstError') ~> SynapseAnalyticsSink

content.query:
SELECT TOP 20 QT.query_sql_text, SP.query_plan,
	RS.min_duration/1000000 as min_duration_sec, 
	RS.avg_duration/1000000 as avg_duration_sec, 
	RS.[max_duration]/1000000 as max_duration_sec,
	RS.min_tempdb_space_used * 8192 / 1024 / 1024 as min_tempdb_MB,
	RS.avg_tempdb_space_used * 8192 / 1024 / 1024 as avg_tempdb_MB,
	RS.max_tempdb_space_used * 8192 / 1024 / 1024 as max_tempdb_MB
FROM sys.query_store_query SQ
INNER JOIN sys.query_store_query_text QT 
	ON SQ.query_text_id = QT.query_text_id
INNER JOIN sys.query_store_plan SP 
	ON SQ.query_id = SP.query_id
INNER JOIN sys.query_store_runtime_stats RS 
	ON SP.plan_id = RS.plan_id
ORDER BY avg_duration DESC

select * from sys.query_context_settings

SELECT current_storage_size_mb, max_storage_size_mb
FROM sys.database_query_store_options;

ALTER DATABASE jhs2gt2acq3getmwpocws1p1
SET QUERY_STORE (
    OPERATION_MODE = READ_WRITE,
    CLEANUP_POLICY = (STALE_QUERY_THRESHOLD_DAYS = 30),
    DATA_FLUSH_INTERVAL_SECONDS = 3000,
    MAX_STORAGE_SIZE_MB = 500,
    INTERVAL_LENGTH_MINUTES = 15,
    SIZE_BASED_CLEANUP_MODE = AUTO,
    QUERY_CAPTURE_MODE = AUTO,
    MAX_PLANS_PER_QUERY = 1000,
    WAIT_STATS_CAPTURE_MODE = ON
);

SELECT name, is_auto_create_stats_on
FROM sys.databases

-- Monitor active queries
SELECT *
FROM sys.dm_pdw_exec_requests
WHERE status not in ('Completed','Failed','Cancelled')
  AND session_id <> session_id()
ORDER BY submit_time DESC;

-- Find top 10 queries longest running queries
SELECT TOP 10 *
FROM sys.dm_pdw_exec_requests
ORDER BY total_elapsed_time DESC;

DROP TABLE IF EXISTS dbo.Student1;

CREATE TABLE Student
(
   [Name]     VARCHAR(50)
  ,[Maths]    INT
  ,[Science]  INT
  ,[English]  INT
);
    
INSERT INTO Student
VALUES
    ('Atul', 'Atul2',     90, 91, 80, 81, 70, 71);
INSERT INTO Student
VALUES
    ('Vishal','Vishal2',  80, 81, 90, 91, 60, 61);
INSERT INTO Student
VALUES
    ('Shailesh', 'Shailesh2', 95, 96, 85, 86, 99, 100);
GO

SELECT * FROM Student; 


SELECT Name1, case when Indicador= 'Maths1'then 1
                when Indicador='Science1' then 2
                else 3
                END as Indicador, Valor1 
FROM   
    (SELECT Name1, Maths1,  Science1, English1 FROM Student) p
UNPIVOT
(
  Valor1
  FOR Indicador in (Maths1, Science1, English1)
) Upt
;

SELECT Name1, Name2, Indicador, Valor1, Valor2
from Student
    cross APPLY (VALUES(Maths1, '1', Maths2, '1'),
                        (Science1, '2',Science2 '2'),
                        (English1, '3', English2 '3')
                        ) unpt (Valor1, Valor2, Indicador);

SELECT s.Name1, s.Name2, unpt.Indicador, unpt.Valor1 
from Student as s
    cross APPLY (values(s.Maths1, '1'),
                        (s.Science1, '2'),
                        (s.English1, '3'))
                         unpt (Valor1, Indicador);

DROP TABLE [dbo].[Student]
GO

SET ANSI_NULLS ON
GO
SET QUOTED_IDENTIFIER ON
GO

CREATE TABLE [dbo].[Student]
( 
	[Name1] [varchar](50)  NULL,
	[Name2] [varchar](50)  NULL,
	[Maths1] [int]  NULL,
	[Maths2] [int]  NULL,
	[Science1] [int]  NULL,
	[Science2] [int]  NULL,
	[English1] [int]  NULL,
	[English2] [int]  NULL
)
WITH
(
	DISTRIBUTION = ROUND_ROBIN,
	CLUSTERED COLUMNSTORE INDEX
)
GO

source: # Using Linux foundation Delta Lake in Synapse Spark
In this notebook, how to read the delta table, how to write to delta table and timetravel is demonstrated

# Set the strorage path info
account_name = 'jhs2gt2acq3getmwpoc' # fill in your primary storage account name
container_name = 'dlsjhspocfs1' # fill in your container name
relative_csv_path = 'source' # fill in your relative CSV folder path
relative_delta_path='DELTA_HRData' # fill in your relative delta lake folder path

adls_path = 'abfss://%s@%s.dfs.core.windows.net/' % (container_name, account_name)
print('Primary storage account path: ' + adls_path)

#csv input file path
csvfilepath = adls_path + relative_csv_path + '/00 HRData.csv'
print ('CSV file path: '+ csvfilepath)

# Delta Lake relative path
deltatablepath = adls_path + relative_delta_path + '/'
print('Delta Lake path: ' + deltatablepath)
### Read data in csv format
csvhrdatadf = spark.read.option("header",True).format("csv").load(csvfilepath)
csvhrdatadf.show(10)
### Write data in delta format
csvhrdatadf.write.mode("overwrite").format("delta").partitionBy("Department").save(deltatablepath)

df_hr = spark.read.format("delta").load(deltatablepath)
df_hr.show(10)
### Check version with timetravel

from pyspark.sql.functions import *
from delta.tables import *

deltaTable = DeltaTable.forPath(spark,deltatablepath)
display(deltaTable.history())

### Update records that match the given condition 
Lets update here PayRate for employees whose payroll is less than 20 to make it lowest payrate value above 20.

minPayRateAbove20 = df_hr.filter("PayRate>20").agg({"PayRate":"min"}).collect()[0]["min(PayRate)"]

#Number of records that will be updated
deltaTable.toDF().filter(col("PayRate")<minPayRateAbove20).count()

### Validate changes by filtering records on condition
Validate no employees have PayRate less than or equal to 20
deltaTableAfterUpdate = DeltaTable.forPath(spark,deltatablepath)
deltaTableAfterUpdate.toDF().filter(col("PayRate")<minPayRateAbove20).count()

## Audit data changes
First Check Version history
display(deltaTable.history())
### Undo changes for DeltaTable by restoring previous version
Lets set the PayRate as it was in previous version

#Get verison 0 details
hrdataversion0 = spark\
                        .read\
                        .format("delta")\
                        .option("versionAsOF",0)\
                        .load(deltatablepath)
print("HR Dataframe as of version 0: ")
hrdataversion0.show(10)

print("In version 0 count of employees who have PayRate less than or equal to 20 are:%d" % hrdataversion0.filter(col("PayRate")<minPayRateAbove20).count())


# Revert changes
hrdataversion0.write.format("delta").mode("overwrite").partitionBy("Department").save(deltatablepath)

#read data and check count of employees again
finalversion = spark.read.format("delta").load(deltatablepath)
print("In latest version count of employees who have PayRate less than or equal to 20 are: %d" % finalversion.filter(col("PayRate")<minPayRateAbove20).count())
finalversion.show(10)
display(deltaTable.history())
# Now work wiht Spark SQL
display(spark.sql("SELECT * FROM delta.`{}` LIMIT 5".format(deltatablepath)))

spark.sql("""
  DROP TABLE IF EXISTS hr_delta
""")
spark.sql("""
  CREATE TABLE hr_delta
  USING DELTA
  LOCATION '{}'
""".format(deltatablepath))
%%sql
SELECT sum(payrate) FROM hr_delta
%%sql
SELECT count(*) FROM hr_delta
%%sql
DESCRIBE history hr_delta

#csv input file path
updatecsvfilepath = adls_path + relative_csv_path + '/01 HRData.csv'
newDataDF = spark.read.option("header",True).format("csv").load(updatecsvfilepath)
newDataDF.show(10)
newDataDF.count()

(newDataDF
  .write
  .format("delta")
  .partitionBy("Department")
  .mode("append")
  .save(deltatablepath)
%%sql
DESCRIBE history hr_delta
# Using Linux foundation Delta Lake in Synapse Spark
In this notebook, how to read the delta table, how to write to delta table and timetravel is demonstrated

# Set the strorage path info
account_name = 'jhs2gt2acq3getmwpoc' # fill in your primary storage account name
container_name = 'dlsjhspocfs1' # fill in your container name
relative_csv_path = 'source' # fill in your relative CSV folder path
relative_delta_path='DELTA_HRData' # fill in your relative delta lake folder path

adls_path = 'abfss://%s@%s.dfs.core.windows.net/' % (container_name, account_name)
print('Primary storage account path: ' + adls_path)

#csv input file path
csvfilepath = adls_path + relative_csv_path + '/00 HRData.csv'
print ('CSV file path: '+ csvfilepath)

# Delta Lake relative path
deltatablepath = adls_path + relative_delta_path + '/'
print('Delta Lake path: ' + deltatablepath)
### Read data in csv format
csvhrdatadf = spark.read.option("header",True).format("csv").load(csvfilepath)
csvhrdatadf.show(10)
### Write data in delta format
csvhrdatadf.write.mode("overwrite").format("delta").partitionBy("Department").save(deltatablepath)
df_hr = spark.read.format("delta").load(deltatablepath)
df_hr.show(10)

from pyspark.sql import functions as F

dfWithDate =  F.to_date(F.to_timestamp(col("YearsOfService"), "M/d/yyyy H:mm"))

dfWithDate.show()
### Add New Column YearsOfService

import pyspark.sql.functions as f

df_hr_service = df_hr.withColumn('YearsOfService',2020-f.year(f.to_timestamp('DateofHire', 'MM/dd/yyyy H:mm')))
df_hr_service.show(5)
### Overwrite the entire delta table
df_hr_service.write.mode("overwrite").format("delta").partitionBy("Department").option("mergeSchema", True).save(deltatablepath)
### Validate delta table is updated with new column
hrdataframe = spark.read.format("delta").load(deltatablepath)
hrdataframe.show(10)

### Check version with timetravel

we can see here yearsOfService column is not present in original delta table

hrdataoriginal = (spark
                    .read
                    .format("delta")
                    .option("versionAsOf",0)
                    .load(deltatablepath)
                    )
hrdataoriginal.show(10)

### Update records that match the given condition 
Lets update here PayRate for employees whose payroll is less than 20 to make it lowest payrate value above 20.

from pyspark.sql.functions import *
from delta.tables import *

deltaTable = DeltaTable.forPath(spark,deltatablepath)

minPayRateAbove20 = hrdataoriginal.filter("PayRate>20").agg({"PayRate":"min"}).collect()[0]["min(PayRate)"]

#Number of records that will be updated
deltaTable.toDF().filter(col("PayRate")<minPayRateAbove20).count()

from pyspark.sql.functions import *
from delta.tables import *

deltaTable = DeltaTable.forPath(spark,deltatablepath)

minPayRateAbove20 = hrdataframe.filter("PayRate>20").agg({"PayRate":"min"}).collect()[0]["min(PayRate)"]

#Number of records that will be updated
deltaTable.toDF().filter(col("PayRate")<minPayRateAbove20).count()

### Validate changes by filtering records on condition
Validate no employees have PayRate less than or equal to 20
deltaTableAfterUpdate = DeltaTable.forPath(spark,deltatablepath)
deltaTableAfterUpdate.toDF().filter(col("PayRate")<minPayRateAbove20).count()

## Audit data changes
or Check Version history
#get version history
deltaTable.history().show()
display(deltaTable.history(1))
### Undo changes for DeltaTable by restoring previous version
Lets set the PayRate as it was in previous version

#Get verison 0 details
hrdataversion0 = spark\
                        .read\
                        .format("delta")\
                        .option("versionAsOF",8)\
                        .load(deltatablepath)
print("HR Dataframe as of version 0: ")
hrdataversion0.show(10)

#totalPayrate0= spark.sql("SELECT sum (payrate) FROM delta.`{}` WHERE payrate <=20".format(deltatablepath)
print("In version 0 count of employees who have PayRate less than or equal to 20 are:%d" % hrdataversion0.filter(col("PayRate")<minPayRateAbove20).agg({"PayRate":"sum"}).collect()[0]["sum(PayRate)"])


# Revert changes
hrdataversion0.write.format("delta").mode("overwrite").partitionBy("Department").save(deltatablepath)

#read data and check count of employees again
finalversion = spark.read.format("delta").load(deltatablepath)
print("In latest version count of employees who have PayRate less than or equal to 20 are: %d" % finalversion.filter(col("PayRate")<minPayRateAbove20).agg({"PayRate":"sum"}).collect()[0]["sum(PayRate)"])
finalversion.show(10)
display(spark.sql("SELECT * FROM delta.`{}` LIMIT 5".format(deltatablepath)))

spark.sql("""
  DROP TABLE IF EXISTS hr_delta
""")
spark.sql("""
  CREATE TABLE hr_delta
  USING DELTA
  LOCATION '{}'
""".format(deltatablepath))

spark.sql("""
  DROP TABLE IF EXISTS hr_delta
""")
%%sql
SELECT sum(payrate) FROM hr_delta
%%sql
SELECT count(*) FROM hr_delta
%%sql
DESCRIBE history hr_delta

#csv input file path
updatecsvfilepath = adls_path + relative_csv_path + '/01 HRData.csv'
newDataDF = spark.read.option("header",True).format("csv").load(updatecsvfilepath)
newDataDF.show(10)
newDataDF.count()

(newDataDF
  .write
  .format("delta")
  .partitionBy("Department")
  .mode("append")
  .save(deltatablepath)

resources.name: [concat(parameters('workspaceName'), '/Data Exploration and ML Modeling - NYC taxi predict using Spark MLlib')]

source:
# Predict NYC Taxi Tips using Spark ML and Azure Open Datasets

The notebook ingests, visualizes, prepares and then trains a model based on an Open Dataset that tracks NYC Yellow Taxi trips and various attributes around them.
The goal is to predict for a given trip whether there will be a tip or not.

 https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/synapse-analytics/spark/apache-spark-machine-learning-mllib-notebook

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

from pyspark.sql.functions import unix_timestamp

from pyspark.sql import SparkSession
from pyspark.sql.types import *
from pyspark.sql.functions import *

from pyspark.ml import Pipeline
from pyspark.ml import PipelineModel
from pyspark.ml.feature import RFormula
from pyspark.ml.feature import OneHotEncoder, StringIndexer, VectorIndexer
from pyspark.ml.classification import LogisticRegression
from pyspark.mllib.evaluation import BinaryClassificationMetrics
from pyspark.ml.evaluation import BinaryClassificationEvaluator

## Ingest Data 

Get a sample data of nyc yellow taxi to make it faster/easier to evaluate different approaches to prep for the modelling phase later in the notebook.

# Import NYC yellow cab data from Azure Open Datasets
from azureml.opendatasets import NycTlcYellow

from datetime import datetime
from dateutil import parser

end_date = parser.parse('2018-05-08 00:00:00')
start_date = parser.parse('2018-05-01 00:00:00')

nyc_tlc = NycTlcYellow(start_date=start_date, end_date=end_date)
nyc_tlc_df = nyc_tlc.to_spark_dataframe()
#To make development easier, faster and less expensive downsample for now
sampled_taxi_df = nyc_tlc_df.sample(True, 0.001, seed=1234)

## Exploratory Data Analysis

Look at the data and evaluate its suitability for use in a model, do this via some basic charts focussed on tip values and relationships.

#The charting package needs a Pandas dataframe or numpy array do the conversion
sampled_taxi_pd_df = sampled_taxi_df.toPandas()

# Look at tips by amount count histogram
ax1 = sampled_taxi_pd_df['tipAmount'].plot(kind='hist', bins=25, facecolor='lightblue')
ax1.set_title('Tip amount distribution')
ax1.set_xlabel('Tip Amount ($)')
ax1.set_ylabel('Counts')
plt.suptitle('')
plt.show()

# How many passengers tip'd by various amounts
ax2 = sampled_taxi_pd_df.boxplot(column=['tipAmount'], by=['passengerCount'])
ax2.set_title('Tip amount by Passenger count')
ax2.set_xlabel('Passenger count') 
ax2.set_ylabel('Tip Amount ($)')
plt.suptitle('')
plt.show()

# Look at the relationship between fare and tip amounts
ax = sampled_taxi_pd_df.plot(kind='scatter', x= 'fareAmount', y = 'tipAmount', c='blue', alpha = 0.10, s=2.5*(sampled_taxi_pd_df['passengerCount']))
ax.set_title('Tip amount by Fare amount')
ax.set_xlabel('Fare Amount ($)')
ax.set_ylabel('Tip Amount ($)')
plt.axis([-2, 80, -2, 20])
plt.suptitle('')
plt.show()

## Data Prep and Featurization

It's clear from the visualizations above that there are a bunch of outliers in the data. These will need to be filtered out in addition there are extra variables that are not going to be useful in the model we build at the end.

Finally there is a need to create some new (derived) variables that will work better with the model.

taxi_df = sampled_taxi_df.select('totalAmount', 'fareAmount', 'tipAmount', 'paymentType', 'rateCodeId', 'passengerCount'\
                                , 'tripDistance', 'tpepPickupDateTime', 'tpepDropoffDateTime'\
                                , date_format('tpepPickupDateTime', 'hh').alias('pickupHour')\
                                , date_format('tpepPickupDateTime', 'EEEE').alias('weekdayString')\
                                , (unix_timestamp(col('tpepDropoffDateTime')) - unix_timestamp(col('tpepPickupDateTime'))).alias('tripTimeSecs')\
                                , (when(col('tipAmount') > 0, 1).otherwise(0)).alias('tipped')
                                )\
                        .filter((sampled_taxi_df.passengerCount > 0) & (sampled_taxi_df.passengerCount < 8)\
                                & (sampled_taxi_df.tipAmount >= 0) & (sampled_taxi_df.tipAmount <= 25)\
                                & (sampled_taxi_df.fareAmount >= 1) & (sampled_taxi_df.fareAmount <= 250)\
                                & (sampled_taxi_df.tipAmount < sampled_taxi_df.fareAmount)\
                                & (sampled_taxi_df.tripDistance > 0) & (sampled_taxi_df.tripDistance <= 100)\
                                & (sampled_taxi_df.rateCodeId <= 5)
                                & (sampled_taxi_df.paymentType.isin({"1", "2"}))

## Data Prep and Featurization Part 2

Having created new variables its now possible to drop the columns they were derived from so that the dataframe that goes into the model is the smallest in terms of number of variables, that is required.

Also create some more features based on new columns from the first round.

taxi_featurised_df = taxi_df.select('totalAmount', 'fareAmount', 'tipAmount', 'paymentType', 'passengerCount'\
                                                , 'tripDistance', 'weekdayString', 'pickupHour','tripTimeSecs','tipped'\
                                                , when((taxi_df.pickupHour <= 6) | (taxi_df.pickupHour >= 20),"Night")\
                                                .when((taxi_df.pickupHour >= 7) & (taxi_df.pickupHour <= 10), "AMRush")\
                                                .when((taxi_df.pickupHour >= 11) & (taxi_df.pickupHour <= 15), "Afternoon")\
                                                .when((taxi_df.pickupHour >= 16) & (taxi_df.pickupHour <= 19), "PMRush")\
                                                .otherwise(0).alias('trafficTimeBins')
                                              )\
                                       .filter((taxi_df.tripTimeSecs >= 30) & (taxi_df.tripTimeSecs <= 7200))

## Encoding

Different ML algorithms support different types of input, for this example Logistic Regression is being used for Binary Classification. This means that any Categorical (string) variables must be converted to numbers.

The process is not as simple as a "map" style function as the relationship between the numbers can introduce a bias in the resulting model, the approach is to index the variable and then encode using a std approach called One Hot Encoding.

This approach requires the encoder to "learn"/fit a model over the data in the Spark instance and then transform based on what was learnt.

## Generation of Testing and Training Data Sets
Simple split, 70% for training and 30% for testing the model. Playing with this ratio may result in different models.

# Decide on the split between training and testing data from the dataframe 
trainingFraction = 0.7
testingFraction = (1-trainingFraction)
seed = 1234

# Split the dataframe into test and training dataframes
train_data_df, test_data_df = encoded_final_df.randomSplit([trainingFraction, testingFraction], seed=seed)

## Train the Model

Train the Logistic Regression model and then evaluate it using Area under ROC as the metric.

## Create a new LR object for the model
logReg = LogisticRegression(maxIter=10, regParam=0.3, labelCol = 'tipped')

## The formula for the model
classFormula = RFormula(formula="tipped ~ pickupHour + weekdayVec + passengerCount + tripTimeSecs + tripDistance + fareAmount + paymentType+ trafficTimeBinsVec")

## Undertake training and create an LR model
lrModel = Pipeline(stages=[classFormula, logReg]).fit(train_data_df)

## Saving the model is optional but its another for of inter session cache
datestamp = datetime.now().strftime('%m-%d-%Y-%s');
fileName = "lrModel_" + datestamp;
logRegDirfilename = fileName;
lrModel.save(logRegDirfilename)

## Predict tip 1/0 (yes/no) on the test dataset, evaluation using AUROC
predictions = lrModel.transform(test_data_df)
predictionAndLabels = predictions.select("label","prediction").rdd
metrics = BinaryClassificationMetrics(predictionAndLabels)
print("Area under ROC = %s" % metrics.areaUnderROC)

## Evaluate and Visualize

Plot the actual curve to develop a better understanding of the model.

## Plot the ROC curve, no need for pandas as this uses the modelSummary object
modelSummary = lrModel.stages[-1].summary

plt.plot([0, 1], [0, 1], 'r--')
plt.plot(modelSummary.roc.select('FPR').collect(),
         modelSummary.roc.select('TPR').collect())
plt.xlabel('False Positive Rate')
plt.ylabel('True Positive Rate')
plt.show()
# Delta Lake OPTIMIZE
### Data preparation
// spark.conf.get("spark.databricks.delta.optimize.maxFileSize")
spark.conf.get("spark.executor.instances")

### Optimize dataset

Optimize will compact small target files into larger files.
Target files are
- smaller than `spark.databricks.delta.optimize.maxFileSize` (default 1GB) AND
- under the corresponding partitions if partition filter condition is specified.

Optimize won't optimize the target files if
- only one file in the partition
- no candidate for compaction e.g. 2 files of 700MB & maxFileSize=1GB
print(spark.conf.get("spark.databricks.delta.optimize.maxFileSize"))
// optimize all files
dt.optimize().show
### Check performance without optimize

def measure(f : => Unit) {
    val start = System.nanoTime
    f
    val durationInMS = (System.nanoTime - start) / 1000 / 1000
    println("duration(ms): " + durationInMS )

// Use version 0 for non-optimized data
val df = spark.read.format("delta").option("versionAsOf", "0").load(dataPath)
val agg = df.agg(avg("colA"))
measure(println(agg.collect))
### Check performance after optimize

// Use the latest version for optimized data
val df = spark.read.format("delta").load(dataPath)
val agg = df.agg(avg("colA"))
measure(println(agg.collect))

### Spark SQL support

Note: partition filter condition does not support in Spark SQL yet.
// This won't optimize anything since the table is already optimized.
spark.sql(s"OPTIMIZE delta.`$dataPath`").show
### zOrder - Example
spark.sql(s"OPTIMIZE delta.`$dataPath` ZORDER BY (ColA)").show
### Temp Area

%%pyspark
from delta.tables import *
dt = DeltaTable.forPath(spark, '/deltaoptimizetest/data-550226')
display(dt.optimize(condition = "colC = 1"))

# display(dt.optimize(condition = "colC = 1", zOrderBy = "colA"))
# help(dt.optimize)
spark.sql(s"CREATE TABLE sampledata USING DELTA LOCATION '$dataPath'")
%%sql
OPTIMIZE sampledata ZORDER BY (ColA)

# Define column headers
columns = ["Employee","Salary"]

# Define data for original dataframe
empOriginal = [("Employee_1",50000),("Employee_2",55000)]

# Define data for updates dataframe
empUpdates = [("Employee_1",50000),("Employee_2",60000),("Employee_3",55000)]

# Create dataframe with orignial employee data
dfOriginal = spark.createDataFrame(data = empOriginal,schema = columns)

# Create dataframe with updated employee data
dfUpdates = spark.createDataFrame(data = empUpdates,schema = columns)

# Display dfOriginal
dfOriginal.show()

# Display dfUpdates
dfUpdates.show()

# Create temp views of both the dfOriginal and dfUpdates dataframes 
# so that we can easily query them with Spark SQL later

#dfOriginal
dfOriginal.createOrReplaceTempView('Employee_Original')

#dfUpdates
dfUpdates.createOrReplaceTempView('Employee_Updates')

%%sql
-- Create Delta Lake table, define schema and location
CREATE TABLE DELTA_Employees (
  Employee STRING NOT NULL,
  Salary INT NOT NULL,
  BeginDate DATE NOT NULL,
  EndDate DATE NOT NULL,
  CurrentRecord INT NOT NULL 
)
USING DELTA
-- specify data lake folder location
LOCATION '/DELTA_Employees/Employees/'

%%sql
-- Merge statement to handle upsert of dfOrginal dataset into DELTA_Employees table
MERGE INTO delta_employees t
USING (
    SELECT emp.Employee AS MergeKey, emp.*
    FROM Employee_Original AS emp

    UNION ALL

    SELECT NULL AS MergeKey, emp.*
    FROM Employee_Original AS emp
    JOIN delta_employees AS de ON emp.Employee = de.Employee
    WHERE de.CurrentRecord = 1 AND emp.Salary <> de.Salary
) s
ON t.Employee = s.MergeKey
WHEN MATCHED AND t.CurrentRecord = 1 AND t.Salary <> s.Salary THEN
  UPDATE SET t.CurrentRecord = 0, t.EndDate = (CURRENT_DATE)
WHEN NOT MATCHED THEN
  INSERT (Employee, Salary, BeginDate, EndDate, CurrentRecord) VALUES (s.Employee, s.Salary, CURRENT_DATE, '2999-12-31',1)

%%sql
SELECT *
FROM DELTA_Employees
ORDER BY Employee
# Delta Lake - Auto compaction

### Auto compaction

Auto compaction will automatically trigger OPTIMIZE operation after any update on the table.

In order to reduce the overhead,
- use 128MB as `maxFileSize` (`spark.microsoft.delta.autoCompact.maxFileSize`, default: 128MB) 
- triggered when there're more than 50 files in a directory. (`spark.microsoft.delta.autoCompact.minNumFiles`, default: 50)
- optimize small files up to the maximum bytes config (`spark.microsoft.delta.autoCompact.maxCompactBytes`, default: 50GB)
val df = spark.read.format("delta").load(dataPath)
println(df.inputFiles.length) // The number of files is 100 * 2 = 200
// Enable auto compaction for all tables.
spark.conf.set("spark.microsoft.delta.autoCompact.enabled", "true")
// Append 1 row to trigger auto compact
df.limit(1).write.mode("append").format("delta").save(dataPath)
val df = spark.read.format("delta").load(dataPath)
println(df.inputFiles.length) // The result should be 2 as there are 2 partitions.
